Hi, I’m Katie Herr

Postdoctoral researcher and NIH IRACDA FIRST Fellow at Emory University

Thank you for visiting my page. This website is still in progress and will continue to be developed.

My passions for biological research and inclusive teaching have motivated my career. Currently, my research is focused on the evolutionary dynamics of insect-microbe symbiosis, using diverse host and microbe systems. To pursue this research, I’ve developed expertise in microbial dynamics, evolutionary biology, next generation sequencing and bioinformatics.

My teaching portfolio.

Cornell

Computational Approaches for Microbial Systems BIOMI 6300

2023

  • Designed learning outcomes and developed a case study from my own research to teach upper- level approaches to bioinformatic analysis and interpretation of next generation sequencing data.
  • Utilized active learning strategies (think-pair-share, popcorn, PollEverywhere survey) to engage students, promote in-class discussion, and assess student take-aways.
  • Learning outcomes:
    • Learn how both genomic and metagenomic sequencing can be harnessed to explore hypotheses
    • Explore trade-offs from different types of sequencing (genomic vs. metagenomic) and different levels of sequencing (shallow vs. deep)

Other work

Blue Heron Biotechnology

Production Associate I

Jun 2017 - Jun 2018

Willamette University

Field Technician

Mar 2017 - Apr 2017

Participated in field research studying pollination biology of Joshua trees (Yucca brevifolia) and coevolution with yucca moths (genus Tegeticula) in Delamar Valley, Lincoln County NV. Installed pollinator exclusion cages, collected flower and leaf samples, and captured yucca moths for study. Endured challenging field conditions such as extreme weather events and limited water supply. Worked and camped in close proximity with a team of four other researchers. Traveled several miles each day carrying water and heavy equipment.
